speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, and how often they occur?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom says they started about a year ago, and they happen pretty often. Sometimes it's just a little bit of bleeding, but sometimes it's really bad and I have to sit still for a while until it stops.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the triggers that seem to cause these bleeding episodes? Is there anything that makes them worse or better?

speaker: Patient
text: "Well, I don't really know what triggers them, but when I get really upset or fall down, it seems to make it worse. And sometimes when I'm playing outside and I get a cut, it bleeds really badly. My mom says it's not always like that, but it happens a lot."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see. It sounds like you have a history of frequent bleeding episodes, which can be concerning. Can you tell me more about your overall health and well-being? Do you have any other symptoms, such as fatigue, joint pain, or swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't feel tired a lot, but sometimes I feel a bit weak after playing outside for a long time. And I don't really hurt when I fall down, but my mom says I'm a bit clumsy sometimes. I just get really frustrated when I'm bleeding a lot."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're experiencing some frustration with the bleeding, and that's understandable. Can you tell me more about your diet and nutrition? Do you have a favorite food or drink that you eat regularly?

speaker: Patient
text: "Hmm, I like pizza and ice cream, and my mom says I eat a lot of fruit and veggies too. I also like drinking juice boxes and sometimes soda, but my mom says that's not good for me, so I try to limit it."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're eating a relatively balanced diet, but with some room for improvement. Can you tell me more about your family history? Do you have any relatives with bleeding disorders or similar health issues? Also, I'd like to perform a physical examination to look for any signs of underlying conditions.

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, my mom says my grandma used to have some problems with her nose, but I don't really know what she meant. And my mom's friend has a cousin who has something with his nose too, but I don't think that's the same thing."

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like there might be some family history of nasal issues, but it's unclear what specific conditions they had. Let's take a closer look at your nasal passages. Can you show me the inside of your nose?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really know how to do that. I'm not really used to looking inside my nose. Can you show me how?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Don't worry, I'll show you. *takes a gentle but firm grip on the patient's head and opens their mouth* Now, I want you to look up and see the inside of your nasal passages. You should see the pink part of your nose and the back of your throat. *gently shines a light to help the patient see* Now, I want you to tell me if you see anything unusual, such as any bleeding, swelling, or abnormalities.

speaker: Patient
text: "I see the inside of my nose... it looks kind of red and stuff. I don't really see anything bleeding, but there are some tiny spots on the inside of my nose that look like they're all swirly. I don't know what they are."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about those swirly spots you saw inside your nose? Are they itchy or tender to the touch? And while we're on the topic of your nasal passages, I'd like to request an imaging test to take a closer look at those swirly spots. REQUEST TEST: Nasal_Soft_Tissue_X-Ray.

text: Can you tell me more about the ELISA Binding Assay results? What does it mean that your platelet surfaces are deficient in GIIb/IIIa receptors?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really know what that means, but my mom says something about it being a problem with my blood. She said the doctor is going to explain it to her and then they'll figure out what to do next."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so the ELISA Binding Assay results indicate that your platelet surfaces have a deficiency in GIIb/IIIa receptors. This means that your platelets have a harder time binding to the blood vessel walls, which can lead to excessive bleeding. It sounds like we're getting close to figuring out what's going on with your bleeding episodes. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling right now? Are you feeling any fatigue, weakness, or dizziness? And while we're on the topic of your platelet count, I'd like to request another test to confirm the results. REQUEST TEST: Platelet_Count. speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I want to explain what the ELISA Binding Assay results mean. It seems that your platelets have a deficiency in GIIb/IIIa receptors, which is a type of receptor on the surface of platelets that helps them bind to the blood vessel walls. Without these receptors, your platelets have a harder time stopping bleeding, which can lead to excessive bleeding episodes. This deficiency is often seen in people with Glanzmann thrombasthenia, a rare bleeding disorder. Can you tell me more about your family history again? Do you have any other relatives with bleeding disorders or similar health issues?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, I don't really know about any other relatives with bleeding disorders, but my mom says my grandma used to have some problems with her nose, like I told you before. And my mom's friend has a cousin who has something with his nose too, but I don't think that's the same thing. Can I ask, what's Glanzmann thrombasthenia? Is it something that can be treated?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "Ah, I'm glad you asked about Glanzmann thrombasthenia. It's a rare bleeding disorder that affects the way platelets work. It's usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that a person needs to inherit two copies of the mutated gene to develop the condition. Unfortunately, that means that many people with the condition may not even show symptoms until they're older. As for treatment, Glanzmann thrombasthenia can be managed with medications that help control bleeding, such as platelet inhibitors. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to repair bleeding sites or remove damaged tissue. Now, I want to ask you a few more questions to confirm the diagnosis. Can you tell me more about your bleeding episodes? How often do they occur, and how long do they last? And while we're on the topic of treatment, I want to discuss the possibility of a bone marrow transplant with you and your parents. It's a treatment option that may be available for some people with Glanzmann thrombasthenia. Also, I'd like to request some further imaging tests to confirm the diagnosis. REQUEST TEST: CT_Scan_of_Bone_Marrow."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for sharing that with me. I want to reassure you and your mom that we're doing everything we can to help you manage your bleeding episodes. Based on the test results, I'm confident that we've identified the underlying cause of your symptoms. Now, I'd like to summarize our findings and discuss the diagnosis. "From our conversation, I understand that you've been experiencing frequent bleeding episodes, including epistaxis, mucous membrane bleeding, and petechiae. Your platelet count is normal, but the ELISA Binding Assay results show that your platelet surfaces have a deficiency in GIIb/IIIa receptors, which is consistent with Glanzmann thrombasthenia. "Furthermore, the imaging tests, including the MRI of the bone marrow, have shown some abnormalities, but they're not specific enough to confirm the diagnosis. However, the Platelet Function Test results are consistent with the ELISA Binding Assay results, which suggests that your platelets are not functioning properly. "Taking all these findings into account, I am confident in diagnosing you with Glanzmann thrombasthenia, a rare bleeding disorder that affects the way platelets work. "DIAGNOSIS READY: Glanzmann Thrombasthenia"
